title: "Do it yourself..." custom JavaFX 2.x controls
summary: Every frontend developer knows the problem, the project you are working on requires a control that is not part of the standard library which raises the question...“How to do a custom control myself ?“ This talk will show you one way you could choose to create those custom controls in JavaFX. The internal structure of a JavaFX control with it‘s different parts like control, skin, behavior and css file will be explained. In addition the differences between a Java Swing component and a JavaFX control will be shown to give the audience with a Swing background an idea on how to convert existing Java Swing components to JavaFX controls. In addition it will be shown how one could get an existing design converted into a control. Therefore a small control will be created in a drawing program and afterwards be converted into code using different approaches like SVG to FXML, FXG to FXML and FXG to Java code.

type.name: Conference
type.description:
• Each conference talk is 50 minutes long
  • They're recorded for Parleys.com
  • Conference speakers receive a full pass.

author.speakerBio:
Gerrit Grunwald is working as a software engineer at Canoo Engineering AG (Basel, Switzerland). He is responsible for visualizations of all kinds. His technical interests include Java desktop software development and specifically the subareas - JavaFX, Java Swing and HTML5 controls.
He‘s a decent frequent blogger, founder and leader of the Java User Group in Münster (Germany), where he‘s also living.
He has been involved in the IT industry since 1996, when he started studying Applied Physics at the University of Applied Sciences Münster (Germany).
author.name: Gerrit Grunwald

user.speakerBio: Freelance since 1997, I am doing everything between developer and information systems architect, having my main emphasis on Java Enterprise Edition 6 technologies. Occasionally, I speak at conferences. I’m founder of the Brussels Java User Group (http://brujug.be) and co-founder of the Random Hacks of Kindness Belgium (http://rhok.be). I’m currently also member of the DEVOXX and DEVOXX4Kids team. Despite of my passion for Java, I still am very connected to more industrial ICT, electronics and low-level programming (Embedded Technologies, Ardiuno, Member of the NAO development program, Lego Mindstorm, C/C++ and much more).  You can find me on twitter @Imifos or on my blog http://www.lucubratory.eu/
user.name: Tasha Carl

user.speakerBio:
David Delabassee is a Product Manager working at Oracle in the GlassFish and Java EE Team. Prior to that, he spent the last 10 years at Sun Microsystems focusing on Java end-to-end (from the smart card to the high end server), all the related technologies, and the developer tools. He has been involved in Java projects since the early days of this technology. David is a steering member of Devoxx, Europe largest Java conference. 
In his spare time, he enjoy tinkering and playing with technologies such as Java, Arduino, Processing, Linux, etc.
user.name: David Delabassee

user.speakingReferences: JavaPolis, Devoxx, JavaOne, JavaZone, Jazoon, JAOO, ..
user.speakerBio:
Stephan Janssen is a serial entrepreneur that has founded several successful organizations such as the Belgian Java User Group (BeJUG) in 1996, JCS Int. in 1998, JavaPolis (now Devoxx) in 2001 and recently Parleys.com in 2006.

He has been using Java since its early releases in 1995 with experience of developing and implementing real world Java solutions in the finance and manufacturing industries.

He was selected by BEA Systems as the first European (independent) BEA Technical Director.

He has also been recognized by the Server Side as one of the 54 Who is Who in Enterprise Java 2004.

Sun has recognized in 2005 his efforts for the Java Community and has engaged Stephan in the Java Champion project.

He has spoken at numerous Java and JUG conferences around the world.
user.name: Stephan Janssen

user.speakerBio: Stephen Chin is a Java Technology Ambassador at Oracle specializing in UI technology and co-author of the Pro JavaFX Platform 2 title, which is the leading technical reference for JavaFX. He has been featured at Java conferences around the world including Devoxx, Codemash, OSCON, J-Fall, GeeCON, Jazoon, and JavaOne, where he twice received a Rock Star Award. In his evenings and weekends, Stephen is an open-source hacker, working on projects including ScalaFX, a DSL for JavaFX in the Scala language, Visage, a UI oriented JVM language, JFXtras, a JavaFX component and extension library, and Apropos, an Agile Project Portfolio scheduling tool written in JavaFX. Stephen can be followed on twitter @steveonjava and reached via his blog: http://steveonjava.com/
user.name: Stephen Chin

user.speakingReferences: Devoxx, JavaOne, BeJUG, SAI, IT Works, ...
user.speakerBio: Jo Voordeckers is no newcomer to the Java community, at JavaOne'08 he spoke on how to implement streaming video in the pre-release of JavaFX and also developed the Parleys.com JavaFX demo for the JavaOne'08 keynote. Next to his day job as a Java, web and mobile developer for Parleys.com and Devoxx, he is active in the Devoxx steering committee and the Belgium JUG where he drives the coding dojo sessions. Jo spends most of his free time experimenting with new technologies and enjoys speaking about Swing, JavaFX, Flex, Mercurial/GIT and lately HTML5. Jo has presented at JavaOne, Devoxx and BeJUG, blogs at blog.pursuit.be and tweets using @jovoordeckers
user.name: Jo Voordeckers
